SENT.plain: Expansion of amino acid homo-sequences, such as polyglutamines or polyalanines, in proteins has been directly implicated in various degenerative diseases through a mechanism of protein misfolding and aggregation
However, it is still unclear how the nature of the expansion and the protein context influence the tendency of a protein to aggregate
Here, we have addressed these questions using spinocerebellar ataxia type-3 (ATX3) protein, the best characterised of the polyglutamine proteins, chosen as a model system
Using a transfected mammalian cell line, we demonstrate that ATX3 aggregation is noticeably reduced by deletion or replacement of regions other than the polyglutamine tract
The nature of the amino acid homo-sequences also has a strong influence on aggregation
From our studies, we draw general conclusions on the effect of the protein architecture and of the amino acid homo-sequence on pathology
